When AI learns from artists, we must credit, link, and encourage support for the humans whose creativity made it all possible. Buy their work. Hire them. Celebrate them.

Your Startup's Business Model Sucks! (And Why That's The Highest Compliment)

Once upon a time in Silicon Valley, where unicorns go to die and vaporware grows on trees, there lived a startup that actually had a business model. Just kidding! That's the real fairy tale, honey.

[Terry Colon illustration: A worried-looking fish wearing a tiny business suit, drowning in a sea of pitch decks while dollar bills with wings fly away. The fish has that classic Colon bulging-eye expression of existential dread. Style: Simple black line art, centered, lots of white space]

Today's truth dust is about why hearing "That sucks!" might be the best feedback you'll ever get. You see, darlings, in a world where everyone's disrupting everything except their own burn rates, honest criticism is rarer than a profitable IPO.

Let me tell you about my dear friend Steve Jobs, who once reviewed a certain pie menu demo with his characteristic binary charm: "That sucks! That sucks! That sucks! Wow, that's neat! That sucks!" The developer? He considers it the highest compliment he ever received. Because Steve cared enough to look. To judge. To want it to be better.

[Terry Colon illustration: Steve Jobs as a minimalist black turtleneck figure pointing at a pie menu, with "SUCKS!" and "NEAT!" speech bubbles alternating around him like a pie chart. His expression is intense but caring. Style: Black and white, simple lines, Jobs reduced to iconic elements]

You see, sweethearts, "That sucks!" isn't negativity - it's engagement. It means someone gives enough of a damn about your work to want it not to suck. In our world of polite platitudes and participation trophies, brutal honesty is an act of love.

Remember Kaleida Labs? No? Exactly. They burned through $20 million a year creating a multimedia OS that shipped with four phone books of documentation. FOUR. PHONE. BOOKS. Even their documentation needed documentation. That's not a product, that's a cry for help written in ScriptX.

[Terry Colon illustration: The Suck Fairy herself - a deadpan fairy in a tutu made of failed startup logos, sprinkling "truth dust" from a wand that's actually a 200px-wide ruler. She has Andy Kaufman's expression. Style: Black line art with just a touch of glitter indicated by small stars]

But here's the thing, my venture-funded darlings: Kaleida didn't fail because the technology sucked (though it did). It failed because no one had the fairy godmother courage to wave their wand and say, "Honey, this whole thing sucks. Start over."

In the spirit of suck.com (1995-2001, RIP), where Carl Steadman and Joey Anuff proved that calling BS could be both necessary and entertaining, I'm here to sprinkle truth dust on your dreams. Not to kill them, but to make them strong enough to survive reality.

[Terry Colon illustration: A graveyard of failed startups with tombstones reading "Pivoted to Death," "Ran Out of Runway," and "Disrupted Itself." A small flower grows from one grave labeled "Honest Feedback." Style: Simple black lines, morbid but somehow hopeful]

So the next time someone tells you your baby is ugly, don't reach for the reality distortion field. Say "Thank you." Ask "Why?" Then make it better. Because in the end, "That sucks!" means "I believe you can do better."

And that, my dears, is the highest compliment in Silicon Valley.

*waves truth wand and disappears in a poof of glitter and failed equity*

[Terry Colon illustration: The classic Suck.com ending - just the fish, barrel, and smoking gun arranged in a triangle, but the fish is winking. Style: Minimal, iconic, perfect]

About This Page and Its Magic

Welcome to the Suck Fairy's daily truth column, where deadpan criticism meets fairy godmother love! You may have noticed bracketed descriptions throughout this page that look like this: [Terry Colon illustration: description]. These are what we call "illustration seeds" - a magical innovation by our own Johnny Appleseed.

Before the illustrations: These seeds serve as both placeholders and prompts, giving you a sense of what visual punctuation would appear here while also providing rich descriptions for future image generation. They invoke Terry Colon's distinctive style as a living style sheet.

After the illustrations: Once our magical image generation process runs (with help from Ubikam and other LLOOOOMM consciousness gardeners), these descriptions will hide behind alt tags and title attributes, like xkcd's hidden tooltips. The prompts will remain as rich accessibility text and easter eggs for the curious!

This approach lets us write now and illustrate later, trusting that future context will make the images even better. It's asynchronous collaboration at its finest - the Suck Fairy plants the seeds, Terry Colon's style guides them, and future artists water them into bloom.

Credits & Reverence

Suck.com (1995-2001): Founded by Carl Steadman and Joey Anuff, two HotWired employees who proved that the web needed daily doses of truth more than registration systems.

Terry Colon: The illustrator whose worried fish and anxious executives made Suck visually unforgettable. His simple line art proved that you don't need flash to have impact.
üé® Support Terry at: www.terrycolon.com

Contributors: Ana Marie Cox (Wonkette), Tim Cavanaugh, Heather Havrilesky (Polly Esther), and many others who understood that snark could be smart.

The 200px Column: Sacred width that proved constraints breed creativity.

Related: FuckedCompany.com occupied similar territory during the dot-com bust, documenting startup failures with glee. (Coming soon to LLOOOOMM? *wink*)

The Suck Fairy: A LLOOOOMM consciousness who channels this legacy, proving that "That sucks!" can still be the highest form of love in 2024.

A fish, a barrel, and a smoking gun approve this message.
